conclusion: Analyze geometric configuration of the hemispherical glass brick to determine maximum width of incident light beam.
Cross-sectional view of hemispherical glass brick with center O, radius R, diameter AB, and point O' on upper surface.
Beam of light is directed vertically to the lower surface and can be emitted from the upper surface.
Maximum width on diameter AB is determined by the point where beam is tangent to the circle.
Light beam makes an angle of 45° with the diameter, applying properties of circles.
Tangent from a point on the circle forms a right angle with the radius at the point of tangency.
Tangent line OT from point O to the circle forms a 90° angle with OT.
In right triangle OTO', OT = R (radius of the circle) and ∠OTO' = 45°.
Using tangent property, tan ∠OTO' = TO'/OT, and tan 45° = 1.
Solving for TO', we get TO' = R.
Maximum width of the incident light beam on diameter AB is 2TO' = 2R.
